nexttext:
where the operator $\mathcal{A}^{\varepsilon}u^{\varepsilon}:=\nabla\cdot\left(-d^{\varepsilon}\nabla u^{\varepsilon}\right)$
involves $d^{\varepsilon}$ termed as the molecular diffusion while
$R$ represents the volume reaction rate. We take into account 
the following assumptions:

$\left(\mbox{A}_{1}\right)$ the diffusion coefficient $d^{\varepsilon}\in L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$
for $d\in\mathbb{N}$ is $Y$-periodic and symmetric, and it guarantees
the ellipticity of $\mathcal{A}^{\varepsilon}$ as follows:

Following standard homogenization procedures, we  deduce the so called auxiliary problems (see e.g. \cite{BLP11}). 
To do so, we consider the functional $\Phi\left(x,y\right)$ depending
on two variables: the macroscopic $x$ and $y=x/\varepsilon$ the
microscopic presentation, and denote by $\Phi^{\varepsilon}\left(x\right)=\Phi\left(x,y\right)$.
The simple chain rule allows us to derive the fact that

The quantities $
abla u^{\varepsilon}$ and $\mathcal{A}^{\varepsilon}u^{\varepsilon}$
must be expended correspondingly. In fact, it follows from \eqref{eq:chain} and \eqref{eq:expansion}
that
 egin{eqnarray}

abla u^{\varepsilon} & = & \left(
abla_{x}+\varepsilon^{-1}
abla_{y}ight)\left(\sum_{m=0}^{M}\varepsilon^{m}u_{m}+\mathcal{O}\left(\varepsilon^{M+1}ight)ight)
onumber \
 & = & \varepsilon^{-1}
abla_{y}u_{0}+\sum_{m=0}^{M-1}\varepsilon^{m}\left(
abla_{x}u_{m}+
abla_{y}u_{m+1}ight)+\mathcal{O}\left(\varepsilon^{M}ight).\label{eq:laplaceu}
\end{eqnarray}


Using the structure of the operator $\mathcal{A}^{\varepsilon}$, we
obtain the following:
 egin{eqnarray}
\mathcal{A}^{\varepsilon}u^{\varepsilon} & = & \varepsilon^{-2}
abla_{y}\cdot\left(-d\left(yight)
abla_{y}u_{0}ight)
onumber \
 &  & +\varepsilon^{-1}\left[
abla_{x}\cdot\left(-d\left(yight)
abla_{y}u_{0}ight)+
abla_{y}\cdot\left(-d\left(yight)\left(
abla_{x}u_{0}+
abla_{y}u_{1}ight)ight)ight]
onumber \
 &  & +\sum_{m=0}^{M-2}\varepsilon^{m}\left[
abla_{x}\cdot\left(-d\left(yight)\left(
abla_{x}u_{m}+
abla_{y}u_{m+1}ight)ight)ight.
onumber \
 &  & \left.+
abla_{y}\cdot\left(-d\left(yight)\left(
abla_{x}u_{m+1}+
abla_{y}u_{m+2}ight)ight)ight]+\mathcal{O}\left(\varepsilon^{M-1}ight).\label{eq:newoperator}
\end{eqnarray}

nexttext:
for $0\le m\le M-2$.

Here, we have denoted by
\begin{eqnarray*}
\mathcal{A}_{0} & := & \nabla_{y}\cdot\left(-d\left(y\right)\nabla_{y}\right),\\
\mathcal{A}_{1} & := & \nabla_{x}\cdot\left(-d\left(y\right)\nabla_{y}\right)+\nabla_{y}\cdot\left(-d\left(y\right)\nabla_{x}\right),\\
\mathcal{A}_{2} & := & \nabla_{x}\cdot\left(-d\left(y\right)\nabla_{x}\right).
\end{eqnarray*}

\begin{rem}
In the case $r\le0$, it is trivial to not only prove the well-posedness
of these auxiliary problems \eqref{eq:prob1}-\eqref{eq:probm}, but
also to compute the solutions by many approaches due to its linearity.
For details, the reader is referred here  to \cite{CP99}.
\end{rem}
The idea is now to linearize the auxiliary problems.  Inspired by the fact that a fixed-point homogenization argument seems to be applicable in this framework, and also by the way a priori  error estimates are proven for difference schemes, we suggest an iteration technique to "linearize" the involved PDE systems.  We start the procedure by choosing  the initial
point $u_{m}^{\left(0\right)}=0$ for $m\in\left\{ 0,...,M\right\}$.
As next step, we consider the following systems corresponding to the nonlinear
auxiliary problems:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{cases}\mathcal{A}_{0}u_{m+2}=R\left(u_{m+2}\right)-\mathcal{A}_{1}u_{m+%
1}-\mathcal{A}_{2}u_{m},&\mbox{in}\;Y_{1},\\
-d\left(y\right)\left(\nabla_{x}u_{m+1}+\nabla_{y}u_{m+2}\right)\cdot\mbox{n}=%
0,&\mbox{on}\;\partial Y_{0},\\
u_{m+2}\;\mbox{is}\;Y-\mbox{periodic in}\;y,\end{cases}" display="block"><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒜</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>u</mi><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒜</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>u</mi><mi>m</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><mtext>in</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>Y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mo>∇</mo><mi>x</mi></msub><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>u</mi><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mo>∇</mo><mi>y</mi></msub><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>u</mi><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>n</mtext></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd in</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd/></mtr></mtable></mrow></math>

for $0\le m\le M-2$.

Here, we have denoted by
\begin{eqnarray*}
\mathcal{A}_{0} & := & \nabla_{y}\cdot\left(-d\left(y\right)\nabla_{y}\right),\\
\mathcal{A}_{1} & := & \nabla_{x}\cdot\left(-d\left(y\right)\nabla_{y}\right)+\nabla_{y}\cdot\left(-d\left(y\right)\nabla_{x}\right),\\
\mathcal{A}_{2} & := & \nabla_{x}\cdot\left(-d\left(y\right)\nabla_{x}\right).
\end{eqnarray*}

\begin{rem}
In the case $r\le0$, it is trivial to not only prove the well-posedness
of these auxiliary problems \eqref{eq:prob1}-\eqref{eq:probm}, but
also to compute the solutions by many approaches due to its linearity.
For details, the reader is referred here  to \cite{CP99}.
\end{rem}
The idea is now to linearize the auxiliary problems.  Inspired by the fact that a fixed-point homogenization argument seems to be applicable in this framework, and also by the way a priori  error estimates are proven for difference schemes, we suggest an iteration technique to "linearize" the involved PDE systems.  We start the procedure by choosing  the initial
point $u_{m}^{\left(0\right)}=0$ for $m\in\left\{ 0,...,M\right\}$.
As next step, we consider the following systems corresponding to the nonlinear
auxiliary problems:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{cases}\mathcal{A}_{0}u_{0}^{\left(n_{0}\right)}=R\left(u_{0}^{\left(n_{%
0}-1\right)}\right),&\mbox{in}\;Y_{1},\\
-d\left(y\right)\nabla_{y}u_{0}^{\left(n_{0}\right)}\cdot\mbox{n}=0,&\mbox{on}%
\;\partial Y_{0},\\
u_{0}^{\left(n_{0}\right)}\;\mbox{is}\;Y-\mbox{periodic in}\;y,\end{cases}" display="block"><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒜</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>u</mi><mn>0</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></msubsup></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msubsup><mi>u</mi><mn>0</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><mtext>in</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>Y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msub><mo>∇</mo><mi>y</mi></msub><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>u</mi><mn>0</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>n</mtext></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><mtext>on</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>Y</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><msubsup><mi>u</mi><mn>0</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></msubsup></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><mtext>is</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>Y</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+2.8pt"><mtext>periodic in</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd/></mtr></mtable></mrow></math>

On the other side, if $\kappa_{p}:=C_{p}L\alpha^{-1}<1$ holds (here  $C_{p}$ is the Poincar\'e constant depending only on the dimension
of $Y_{1}$), we easily obtain that for every $m$, $\left\{ u_{m}^{\left(n_{m}\right)}\right\} $
is a Cauchy sequence in $H^{1}\left(Y_{1}\right)$. Hereby, it naturally
claims the existence and uniqueness of the nonlinear auxiliary problems
\eqref{eq:prob1}-\eqref{eq:probm}. Moreover, the convergence rate
of the iteration procedure is given by

Summarizing, we state our results in the frame of  the following theorems.
\begin{thm}
Suppose \eqref{eq:newR} holds for $r\in\left\{ 1,2\right\} $ and
assume $\kappa_{p}:=C_{p}L\alpha^{-1}<1$ for the given Poincar\'e
constant. Let $\left\{ u_{m}^{\left(n_{m}\right)}\right\} _{n_{m}\in\mathbb{N}}$
be the schemes that approximate the nonlinear auxiliary problems \eqref{eq:prob1-1}-\eqref{eq:probm-1}.
Then \eqref{eq:prob1-1}-\eqref{eq:probm-1} admit a unique solution
$u_{m}$ for all $m\in\left\{ 0,...,M\right\} $ with the speed of
convergence:

which finally leads to $\left\Vert \varphi^{\varepsilon}\right\Vert _{V^{\varepsilon}}\le C\varepsilon^{\frac{M-1}{2}}$
by choosing $\varphi=\varphi^{\varepsilon}$, very much in the spirit of energy estimates.

Summarizing, we state our results in the frame of  the following theorems.
\begin{thm}
Suppose \eqref{eq:newR} holds for $r\in\left\{ 1,2\right\} $ and
assume $\kappa_{p}:=C_{p}L\alpha^{-1}<1$ for the given Poincar\'e
constant. Let $\left\{ u_{m}^{\left(n_{m}\right)}\right\} _{n_{m}\in\mathbb{N}}$
be the schemes that approximate the nonlinear auxiliary problems \eqref{eq:prob1-1}-\eqref{eq:probm-1}.
Then \eqref{eq:prob1-1}-\eqref{eq:probm-1} admit a unique solution
$u_{m}$ for all $m\in\left\{ 0,...,M\right\} $ with the speed of
convergence:
